Project Description  The Project builds on lessons from previous ADB investments 
in  the  small-scale  (less  than  1,000  hectare  [ha])  water 
resources  sector;  specifically,  the  Small-Scale  Water 
Resources Development Sector Project (SSW 1), which was 
implemented  from  1996  to  2002  and  developed  280 
subprojects  in  the  western  part  of  the  country.  Also,  the 
ongoing Second Small-Scale Water Resources Development 
Sector Project (SSW 2), which commenced in 2002 and is due 
to be completed in 2009. This has developed 275 subprojects 
in 61 of 64 districts of Bangladesh. 
The Project will support the development of inclusive water 
management cooperative associations (WMCAS) that include 
landowners,  land  operators,  women,  fishers,  and  other 
vulnerable groups. The WMCAS should have sufficient social 
and technical capital to undertake small-scale water resources 
(SSWR) subprojects and to improve system operations. They 
should have clear financing partnerships and/or cost-sharing 
mechanisms so they can carry out sustainable maintenance. 
Within  an  enabling  institutional  framework,  they  should  be 
capable  of  maximizing  their  collective  potential  to  increase 
agriculture production in the subproject areas. The Project will 
have three outputs: (i) institutional strengthening of government 
agencies  at  all  levels  to  support  SSWR  development; 
(ii)  participatory  subprojects,  which  will  include  poor  and 
vulnerable  groups,  and  which  will  enable  WMCAs  to  plan, 
implement,  operate,  and  maintain  subprojects;  and 
(iii)  construction  and  maintenance  of  up  to  230  SSWR

ii 
 
subprojects  and  performance  enhancement  of  up  to  150 
subprojects (out of 560 completed) from SSW 1 and 2 projects. 
   
Rationale  About  80%  of  Bangladesh's  population  is  rural  and  mainly 
engaged in agriculture and related nonfarm activities. Although 
agriculture’s share of gross domestic product (GDP), currently 
about  20%,  has  been  declining,  it  remains  the  primary 
economic  sector  in  rural  Bangladesh  and  provides  63%  of 
employment. More than two-thirds of the rural population is 
landless or functionally landless (owning less than 0.2 ha of 
land).  Even  productive  land  is  subject  to  regular  flooding. 
Bangladesh has limited land and other natural resources and a 
high population density; as a result, rural poverty is as high as 
53%.  The  rural  poor  face  unfavorable  agricultural 
environments,  rely  heavily  on  agricultural  wage  labor,  and 
possess few agricultural and nonagricultural assets.  
Bangladesh is at the confluence of three major rivers and its 
flat topography, frequent flooding, river erosion, and seasonal 
water  shortages,  combined  with  the  predicted  impacts  of 
climate change, are key challenges. These are aggravated by 
inadequate  water  management  infrastructure,  limited 
beneficiary participation, and poor operation and maintenance 
(O&M)  of  water  resources  infrastructure.  Increasing 
urbanization  and  the  expansion  of  fish  production  on 
agricultural land is forecast to result in a 1.64 million ha decline 
in agricultural land by 2050. Yields will need to increase by 
20% to compensate for the loss of agricultural land. Effective 
water management and equitable access to water within an 
enabling policy and institutional framework are critical for the 
production base and livelihoods of rural poor. 
The Project will support the National Strategy for Accelerated 
Poverty Reduction II of the Government of Bangladesh, which 
identifies water resources development and management as a 
critical sector for pro-poor economic growth and food security 
through agricultural development. The Project implements key 
elements  of  ADB’s  Water  Policy  including  institutional 
strengthening  and  socially  inclusive  development  principles, 
including stakeholder consultation and participation at all levels. 
It  also  supports  core  areas  of  operations  defined  in  ADB’s 
Strategy  2020,  including  investing  in  rural  infrastructure  for 
water management, building capacity for better infrastructure 
management, and promoting institutional reforms that enhance 
operational  efficiency  and  sustainability  of  infrastructure 
projects. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the Project will be enhanced productivity and 
sustainability in agriculture in subproject areas. The outcome of 
the  Project  will  be  sustainable  small-scale  water  resources 
management systems in subproject areas.

Project Investment Plan  The  investment  cost  of  the  Project  is  estimated  at 
$107.3 million, including taxes and duties of $12.7 million. 
   
Financing Plan  The Government has requested a loan of $55.0 million from 
ADB's Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the 
rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
annum thereafter; a term of 32 years, including a grace period 
of 8 years, to finance 51.3% of project costs. An International 
Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) loan in the amount of 
$22.0 million to finance about 20.5% of project costs will be 
provided as cofinancing and will be administered by ADB. The 
IFAD loan will have a 40-year term with an annual service 
charge of 0.75% (and a 10-year grace period before repayment 
of the principal amount begins). The Government will provide 
$26.6 million equivalent to finance 24.8% of project costs to 
cover land acquisition and resettlement, tax and duties, and 
incremental  recurrent  costs.  Project  beneficiaries  will  be 
responsible for funding the operation and maintenance of water 
management  civil  works  and  will  contribute  $3.7  million 
equivalent to finance 3.5% of project costs.

Implementation  The Integrated Water Resources Management Unit (IWRMU) 
Arrangements  within LGED is responsible for overall development, O&M, and 
monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  support  for  SSWR 
subprojects.  A  project  management  office  (PMO)  will  be 
established within IWRMU to manage and coordinate project 
activities. The PMO will receive support from four specialist 
sections  of  IWRMU  and  from  project  implementation 
consultants.  Ten  regional  offices  of  LGED,  intermediary  to 
headquarters  and  district  levels,  will  provide  training, 
supervision, inspection and monitoring functions for completed 
subprojects. A steering committee will be established for overall 
coordination of concerned ministries and agencies. Planning 
and implementation committees at district and local levels will 
ensure  smooth  coordination.  Local  governments,  LGED 
regional and district offices, specialist facilitators recruited from 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  or  firms,  and  local 
community  assistants  will  help  to  form  the  WMCAs. 
Departments  of  Cooperatives,  Agricultural  Extension  and 
Fisheries will help to build their capacity by providing extension 
support  services.  Civil  works  will  be  initiated  following 
establishment  and  capacity  building  of  WMCAs  who  will 
assume O&M responsibilities on completion of the subprojects. 
   
Procurement  Procurement of works, goods, and services financed by the 
ADB and IFAD loans will be carried out in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to  time)  and,  for  national  competitive  bidding  (NCB),  the 
Government’s  applicable  public  procurement  regulations 
acceptable  to  ADB.  International  competitive  bidding  (ICB) 
procedures will be followed for contracts of works for more than 
$2 million and national competitive bidding (NCB) procedures 
for contracts of works of $2 million and below. Most civil works 
will  be  carried  out  through  NCB,  given  the  small  size  of 
subprojects.  Goods  will  be  procured  under  ICB  where  the 
estimated cost is more than $1,000,000 equivalent and NCB for 
contracts from $100,000 to $1,000,000. Shopping procedures 
will be used for contracts with estimated cost between $10,000 
and  $100,000.  Contracts  below  $10,000  and  earthworks 
contracts costing less than Tk330,000 (about $5,000) may be 
awarded  based  on  direct  contracting.  In  such  cases,  ADB 
should be satisfied that the price paid is reasonable. 
   
Consulting Services  Consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). The Government will select and engage, using 
the  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  (QCBS)  method,  one 
international  consulting  firm  for  the  project  implementation 
consultancy (PIC) at an estimated cost of $6.5 million. The PIC 
will comprise a total of 1,092 person-months, comprising 64 
international and 1,028 national person-months. The PIC will 
provide experts in (i) institutional strengthening and capacity

building,  (ii)  quality  control  of  engineering  design  and 
supervision of civil works, and (iii) social and environmental 
safeguard  requirements.  National  consulting  firms  will  be 
recruited using QCBS to prepare subproject feasibility studies 
and detailed engineering designs. NGOs will be recruited using 
QCBS  to  provide  agriculture  and  fisheries  enhancement 
training  and  O&M  support.  Individuals  will  be  recruited  as 
community  assistants  in  accordance  with  specific  selection 
criteria acceptable to ADB. Firms, institutes, or NGOs will be 
recruited  using  least-cost  selection  for  participatory  rural 
appraisal  under  the  benefit  monitoring  evaluation  study  and 
baseline impact evaluation. 
   
Project Benefits and  The Project will improve rural livelihoods through nationwide 
Beneficiaries  financing  of  investments  in  participatory  small-scale  water 
resources management, including flood management, drainage 
improvement,  water  conservation,  and  command  area 
development  (includes  activities  to  improve  surface  water 
irrigation such as providing field channels and pipe systems), 
benefiting 209,000 ha of cultivable land. It will directly benefit 
324,400 households (about 1.7 million people) through more 
intense cropping systems, increased culture fishing areas, and 
greater crop and fish yields. For the three sample subprojects, 
over  80%  of  direct  beneficiaries  were  poor.  The  estimated 
poverty impact ratio (the percentage of the net financial benefits 
plus the economic surplus flowing to poor households divided 
by  the  total  net  financial  benefits  and  economic  surplus)  is 
calculated  at  0.65.  The  economic  rate  of  return  for  the 
subprojects ranges from 26% to 28% and for the overall Project 
it  is  29%.  Flood  management  and  drainage  improvement 
subprojects are also expected to reduce damage to public and 
private infrastructure significantly and to contribute to measures 
to  adapt  to  climate  change.  Requiring  WMCA  management 
committees to have a one-third representation by women will 
raise the status of women in the community and encourage 
women  to  participate  in  income-generating  activities  and 
employment. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The main risks are that infrastructure investments will not be 
sustainable and actions for institutional strengthening will not 
be taken in a timely manner—both of which are addressed in 
the project design. LGED and WMCAs need to be reoriented 
on system O&M to improve the sustainability of subprojects. 
Upfront cash contributions are insufficient to instill ownership 
and  perpetuate  system  maintenance,  so  the  Project  will 
introduce a more broad based approach to maintenance that 
considers technical, institutional, financial, and social aspects. 
Improvements to LGED management will steadily increase the 
rate of subproject implementation. The role of IWRMU will be 
strengthened  to  involve  it  more  deeply  in  subproject 
development and postconstruction support. IWRMU and LGED

vi 
 
regional and district offices (accompanied by greater human 
and fiscal resources) will guide future investments in the sector 
and  provide  continuous  technical  and  institutional  support. 
Systems are in place and will be improved by the Project for 
demand-driven  subproject  selection,  technical  feasibility 
analysis  of  subprojects,  resettlement  planning  and 
implementation, and construction management. The Project will 
also strengthen WMCAs to maximize inclusiveness, particularly 
of poor and vulnerable people in decision making and project 
benefits.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) proposed administration of a loan to be provided by the International Fund for 
Agricultural  Development  (IFAD),  both  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the 
Participatory Small-Scale Water Resources Sector Project. 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  In December 2007, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved project preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA)1 to help the Local Government Engineering Department (LGED) 
formulate the Participatory Small-Scale Water Resources Sector Project. This report is based 
on the analysis and sample subproject feasibility studies of the PPTA (Supplementary Appendix 
A), findings of ADB missions, and discussions with officials and stakeholders. The project 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  With a population2 of over 150 million living in an area of 147,570 square kilometers 
(1,045  persons  per  square  kilometer),  Bangladesh  is  one  of  the  most  densely  populated 
countries in the world. About 80% of the population lives in rural areas and is mainly engaged in 
agriculture  and  related  nonfarm  activities.  More  than  two-thirds  of  the  rural  population  is 
landless or functionally landless (owning less than 0.2 hectares [ha] of land). The national 
poverty headcount ratio declined from 56.6% in 1991 to 48.9% in 2000 and further to 40% in 
2005.3 The rural poverty rate is now between 44% and 53%.4 Bangladesh has limited land and 
other natural resources, and a high population density. As a result, rural poverty is pervasive.  
4.  Bangladesh has achieved impressive economic and social gains over the past decade, 
including GDP growth of 5%–6%, relatively low inflation, and fairly stable domestic debt, interest 
rates, and exchange rates. Its growth has been remarkably resilient despite numerous natural 
disasters and some erosion in business confidence. Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth 
in FY2008 remained strong at 6.2%, supported by more domestic economic activity in the 
second half of FY2008. Human poverty trends have improved more quickly than income poverty 
trends. The human poverty index (based on deprivations in health, education, and nutrition) was 
61% in the early 1980s, declined to 47% in the early 1990s and dropped further to 35% in the 
late 1990s. The index of human poverty has declined annually by 2.5% compared with a 1.5% 
decline in the poverty headcount ratio for income poverty since late 1980s.5 
5.  Despite this progress, Bangladesh remains one of the world’s least developed countries 
with GDP per capita of $555 (FY2008), poverty incidence of up to 53%, and a 48% child 
malnutrition  rate  (footnote  5).  Although  agriculture’s  share  of  GDP  (about  20%)  has  been 
declining as the economy grows, it remains the primary economic sector in rural Bangladesh 
and provides 63% of rural employment. Food crops represent about 72% of the value added by 
agriculture, followed by fisheries (11%), livestock (10%), and forestry (7%).

6.  The Government has an aggressive set of development targets based on the 2015 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). These include (i) eradicating extreme poverty and 
hunger by halving, between 1990 and 2015, the proportion of people whose income is less than 
$1 a day; and (ii) reducing the proportion of malnourished children under five by 50%. The 
National Strategy for Accelerated Poverty Reduction (NSAPR) II acknowledges the potential 
impact of global climate change on Bangladesh and identifies water resources development and 
management as a critical sector for pro-poor policies to achieve economic growth and food 
security through agricultural development (footnote 3). NSAPR II is fully consistent with the 
MDGs  and  aims  to  achieve  substantial  improvement  in  almost  all  aspects  of  human 
development.  
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
7.  Poverty in Bangladesh is primarily rural and has many dimensions. Women are more 
vulnerable than men to poverty. Poverty headcount ratios (for 2008) range from 32% in Dhaka 
to over 50% in Barisal district. Extreme and chronic poverty persists, particularly for people 
living in remote and vulnerable areas such as riverbanks (footnote 3). Meeting the MDG target 
for poverty reduction will require a sustained GDP growth rate6 of 4% in agriculture and 7% in 
the nonfarm sector, a formidable task. 
8.  Water  resources  management.  Bangladesh  faces  significant  physical  challenges 
because of its flat topography7 and its location at the confluence of three major transboundary 
rivers—the  Brahmaputra,  the  Ganges,  and  the  Meghna.  On  average,  20%  of  the  country 
experiences monsoon flooding over banks and faulty drainage. Severe flooding with about 60% 
of the country under water occurs about every decade. Periodic natural disasters (including 
cyclones and tidal surges) and dry season droughts have severe impacts on agriculture,8 
fisheries, and livelihoods of people living in affected areas.9 Greater use of groundwater for 
agriculture and consumption and its deteriorating quality (specifically arsenic contamination of 
over 30% of groundwater resources10) has serious implications for health, soil degradation, and 
agricultural yields. Bangladesh needs to reduce its reliance on groundwater by improving the 
management  of  surface  water  through  flood  management,  drainage  improvement,  water 
conservation, and by improving the reliability and efficiency of irrigation supplies in command 
areas.11 
9.  Physical challenges are exacerbated by inadequate water management infrastructure, 
limited  beneficiary  participation,  and  weak  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M).  Increasing 
urbanization and an expansion of fish production on agricultural land (as culturable wasteland is 
utilized) is forecast to result in a loss of 1.64 million ha of agricultural land by 2050. Yields will 
need to increase by 20% to compensate for the loss of this land. Effective water management 
and equitable access to water are critical for the production base and livelihoods of the rural 
poor. Improvements to water resource infrastructure, including embankments, and water control

to $686 per ton—still 110% higher than the 2007 price. 
11.  Food price surges (mainly for rice) in 2008 seriously eroded the purchasing capacity of 
people living below the poverty line. According to a 2008 study15 on the weighted inflationary 
impact of the price of rice, an additional 8.5% of households (2.5 million households or 12 
million people) fell below the poverty line in 2008. People below the poverty line saw their 
incomes eroded by 36.7% from January 2007 to March 2008. Continued significant growth in 
food crop production is critical to tackling rural poverty. Efforts to increase food grain production 
need to be continued to keep pace with population growth and to ensure food security for the 
poor. Providing effective and sustainable water management infrastructure is an important part 
of this effort. 
12.  Vulnerability to climate change. Climate change is a pressing development challenge 
for Bangladesh. Projected impacts16 include an increase in temperature of over 1.0°C by 2050 
and average sea level rises of 30 cm by 2050, which could make an additional 14% of the 
country extremely vulnerable to floods and dislocate more than 35 million people from coastal 
districts. With rising sea surface temperatures, the intensity and frequency of cyclones and 
storm  surges  are  also  likely  to  increase.  Poor  communities,  which  are  disproportionately 
dependent on marginal lands including the coastal belt, will be most affected. 
13.  Climate change threatens the significant achievements made by Bangladesh in the last 
20  years  in  raising  incomes  and  reducing  poverty.  It  also  poses  major  threats  to  the 
achievement  of  the  MDGs,  particularly  those  on  eliminating  poverty  and  promoting 
environmental sustainability. Rising temperatures and changing rainfall patterns, along with 
higher flooding and rising salinity in the coastal belt are likely to reduce crop production. The 
Intergovernmental  Panel  for  Climate  Change  estimates  that  by  2050  rice  production  in 
Bangladesh could have declined by 8% and wheat by 32% from 1990 levels. In southeast 
Bangladesh, an estimated 14,000 tons a year of grain production could be lost because of sea 
level rises by 2030 and 252,000 tons a year could be lost by 2075. Greater requirements for 
fertilizers, pesticides, and irrigation may result in higher production costs.

14.  Sustainability of water resources infrastructure. Since 1980, more than $6 billion has 
been invested in water resources infrastructure in Bangladesh, mainly for flood management, 
drainage, irrigation and riverbank protection. A weakness that continues to plague investments 
in the water sector is the lack of long-term O&M of water management facilities. Deferred or 
nonexistent maintenance of such facilities has direct impacts on productivity, rural incomes, and 
poverty. It leads to a deterioration of infrastructure, causing (i) reductions in irrigated areas;      
(ii) increases in inundation because of drainage congestion; and (iii) an insufficient supply of 
irrigation water.  
15.  The issue is complicated by inadequate financing,17 beneficiary disengagement, weak 
service  delivery,  and  an  inability  to  move  beyond  relatively  short-term  project-related 
commitments. The sustainability of water resources management systems by strengthening 
local  water  management  institutions  is  central  to  safeguarding  investments  made  in  water 
resources. Technical service providers also need strengthening18 and reorienting so they can 
support and mentor local water management institutions to help them carry out O&M. Strategic 
direction and clarity in postconstruction support for O&M, its operationalization through a distinct 
stage  of  the  subproject  development  process,  and  reorientation  of  service  providers  for 
specialized institutional and technical support are key challenges. 
16.  Strengthening policy, institutional, and fiscal arrangements. The Government has 
maximized  efforts  since  1990  to  establish  a  policy  framework  to  address  complex  water 
resources issues. The adoption of the National Water Policy (NWP) in 1999 provided clear 
policy goals and principles for integrated and participatory water management, decentralization, 
better governance, and sustainable O&M, combined with decentralization of management. The 
NWP  identifies  establishment  of  a  legislative  framework  as  fundamental  to  effective 
implementation of the policy’s principles and policy goals. In support of the NWP, ADB has 
facilitated policy reforms for the water sector through a regional technical assistance (TA) 
project for Process Development for Preparing and Implementing Integrated Water Resources 
Management Plans.19 Under this TA project, the draft National Water Act has been expanded 
and finalized. A suggested road map for the sector and potential areas of ADB assistance 
(Appendix 2) has also been prepared. The TA project is supporting the periodic review and 
updating  of  the  NWMP  and  has  identified  actions  for  improvement  in  river  and  flood 
management,  drainage,  irrigation  facilities,  and  sustainable  O&M.  The  National  Water 
Management Plan (NWMP), which was approved in 2004, has been an important outcome of 
the NWP. This 25-year investment plan is designed to coordinate water resources and related 
sector development activities.

Bangladesh,  water  management  interventions  require  cross-sectoral  perspectives  and 
stakeholder  consultation.  The  Government  approved  guidelines  for  participatory  water

sound institutional development. To provide a  legal framework for the operation of cooperatives, 
the Cooperatives Ordinance, 1984 and Cooperatives Societies Rules, 1987 were amended in

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Sector Investment 
25.  The Project will finance subproject investments in the small-scale water resources sector, 
in particular the provision of flood management, drainage, water conservation, access to surface 
water for irrigation during the dry season, and command area development subprojects. The 
Project will develop 230 new subprojects in 46 out of 61 districts32 of Bangladesh, excluding 
three districts of Chittagong Hill Tracts and 15 districts in which similar subprojects are being 
financed by the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) under its Small-Scale Water 
Resources Development Project.33 The performance of existing SSW 1 and SSW 2 subprojects 
will be improved in 61 districts (excluding three districts of the Chittagong Hill Tracts). Three 
sample subprojects have been prepared to assess the technical, social, financial, economic, 
and  environmental  feasibility  of  subsequent  subprojects  and  of  the  overall  Project.  The 
Kanakdia  and  Purba  Sarail-Madai  subprojects  provide  flood  management  and  drainage 
improvements, while the Goshinga subproject is focused on command area development and 
improvements to the irrigation distribution system. Subproject feasibility studies are presented in 
Supplementary Appendix A.

subproject areas. The outcome of the Project will be sustainable small-scale water resources

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits and Impacts 
57.  The Project will improve rural livelihoods through the nationwide financing of investments 
in  participatory  small-scale  water  resources  management,  including  flood  management, 
drainage  improvement,  water  conservation,  and  command  area  development,  benefiting 
209,000 ha of cultivable land. It will provide direct benefits to 324,400 households in the form of 
intensification of cropping systems, increased culture fishing areas, and greater crop and fish 
yields. Up to 230 subprojects51 will be supported and an additional 150 SSW 1 and SSW 2 
subprojects will be provided with technical and institutional support for low-cost, quick-yielding 
benefits. The Project will generate significant social and economic benefits, including improved 
living conditions and livelihood opportunities for communities living in flood-risk and drought-
prone areas. Flood management and drainage improvement subprojects are also expected to 
reduce damage to public and private infrastructure significantly and to contribute to adaptive52 
measures for climate change.  
58.  During the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA), a comprehensive study was 
carried out at three subprojects, which were selected to represent53 about 230 small-scale water 
resources schemes throughout the country. The study indicated that these subprojects would 
deliver  agricultural  benefits  that  met  local  needs  and  priorities.  Environmental,  social,  and 
poverty impacts were expected to be positive. Over 80% of subproject beneficiaries in the three 
subproject areas were small, marginal, or landless farmers. The estimated poverty impact ratio54 
was calculated at 0.65, which is reasonable considering the proportion of land operated by large 
or medium-sized households. 
1.  Financial Analysis 
59.  Crop  and  fisheries  budgets  were  prepared  for  individual  subprojects  and  with-  and 
without-project  scenarios  were  compared.  Significant  revenue  from  the  subprojects  will  be 
derived from making the land more productive by reducing submergence during the monsoon 
season and drought in winter. New crop technologies will help to diversify cropping patterns, 
increase cropping intensities, and improve yields. The move from local, traditional varieties of 
rice  to  high-yielding  aman  and  boro  rice  significantly  improves  yields.  Improved  cropping 
technologies usually result in a need for more labor at a higher rate, generally $4–$5 per day, 
providing a solid incentive for farm families to invest in the Project. Incremental employment 
generated by subproject activities (for the entire Project) is estimated to be 118,000 person-
days, of which about 30% will be incremental labor by women. The average incremental net 
agricultural income per household covered by the Project will increase by up to 68%. Small, 
marginal,  or  landless  households  will  receive  up  to  46%  of  the  financial  benefits  at  full 
development. Financial internal rates of return (FIRR) estimated for the sample subprojects are 
robust, ranging from 20% to 27%, reflecting their ability to recover investment and operating 
costs. The estimated financial benefit–cost55 ratio is 1.4 and the overall project FIRR is 28%.

2.  Economic Analysis 
60.  The economic analysis has drawn together project investment costs over an 8-year 
implementation period, including recurrent costs needed to ensure sustainable benefits, and 
compares them with the quantified incremental benefits over a 20-year period. Crop production 
benefits will result mainly from increased yields, the greater area of less-flood-prone land, 
adoption of higher-value crops, more irrigation and improved agricultural practices, as detailed 
above. Fisheries production, a small part of the benefits, will be maintained. Land use changes 
will result in an increase in cropping intensities rather than in the cropped area. The current 
overall cropping intensity is 161% and this is expected to increase to 173%, with the boro area 
increasing from 69% to 76% of the total cropped area. The Project will produce 56% more aman 
rice than currently and increases of 33% in aus and 29% in wheat.  
61.  In 2008, world cereal markets were volatile, supplies were tight, and demand was rising, 
making the market sensitive to shocks. Mean rice prices in 2008 were $650 per ton, compared 
with prices of $286 in 2005, and $580 in January 2009.56 World Bank price projections show the 
real price of rice falling back to $404 per ton from 2010, although this is still higher than in 2007. 
This gives rice a conversion factor ranging from 0.8 to 1.5, depending on the world price 
adopted. Using 2010 prices, the conversion factor is 1.0, which is used in the economic analysis. 
For the sample subprojects, economic internal rates of return (EIRR) range from 26% to 28%, 
giving an overall project EIRR of 29%. Switching values indicate that the Project is sensitive to 
delays in benefits, although it remains economically viable at 14% with a 2-year delay. The 
Project is insensitive to increased investment cost, crop production, or O&M costs. 
B.  Social Dimensions 
1.  Social Benefits 
62.  The Project is expected to make significant contributions to poverty reduction in project 
areas. Direct benefits are expected through increases in household income by incremental net 
increases in the value of agricultural production, and higher returns to labor involved in this 
incremental production. Additional irrigation is expected to increase production of high-yielding 
rice varieties and additional crops. 
63.  It is estimated that poor households will receive 46% of the total financial benefits at full 
development.  Of  the  benefits,  32%  will  be  distributed  to  large  and  medium-sized  farmer 
households, 32% to small farmer households, 13% to marginal farmer households, 15% to 
landless  households  (sharecroppers  and  tenants),  and  9%  to  labor.  Increases  in  local 
household income and food production improve the nutritional status of the populations in the 
subproject areas. There will also be opportunities for increased income from culture fishing in 
ponds. While the poor own on average only just over half the total arable land, they rent 
additional land and thus operate up to 80% of the land in subproject areas. It is anticipated that 
they will benefit from higher labor incomes from increases in crop production. In addition, the 
labor for the earthworks involved in project construction is likely to be drawn from local poor 
households. Women’s participation in WMCAs, which includes their one-third membership of 
the management committee, will provide benefits from employment opportunities created and 
other services provided to WMCAs (see poverty analysis in Supplementary Appendix L).

management and drainage and reduce effects of early floods during pre-monsoon and post-
monsoon water logging. Other subprojects will provide water storage for irrigation during the dry

65.  Subprojects will be selected and environmental assessment for each undertaken in 
accordance with environmental assessment and review procedures prepared for the Project to

water management through better agronomic practices; and (ii) increased adoption of integrated 
pest management through intensive agriculture extension services. Subprojects will aim to 
reduce  potential  adverse  impacts  on  subsistence  floodplain  fisheries,  through  better 
management of gate operation and aquaculture.

analysis and a soil fertility level examination to assist farmers in determining fertilizer mixes and 
applications,  and  to  verify  any  long-term  effect  on  soil  quality  degradation;  (v)  providing 
environmental education and training to raise awareness among stakeholders on sustainable 
use of local resources; and (vi) providing culture fishery training to compensate for partial loss of

SMALL-SCALE WATER RESOURCES SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Background and Issues 
1.  Bangladesh is in an alluvial deltaic floodplain in the confluence of three major rivers—the 
Ganges, Brahmaputra, and Meghna. These rivers have a catchment area of 1.74 million square 
kilometers (km2) and display substantial seasonal variability of flows, leading to severe flooding, 
sedimentation, and riverbank erosion, causing social hardship for the rural poor. Flooding is 
seasonal and there is often drought in the dry season. Coastal and estuarine areas suffer from 
saline intrusion and associated environmental degradation as well as periodic cyclones and tidal 
surges—further exacerbated by climate change impacts. Arsenic contamination of groundwater 
is widespread, resulting in significant health implications. Water management is complicated by 
the  diverse  livelihood  activities  of  rural  poor,  including agriculture, fisheries,  transportation, 
industries,  and  water  supply.  Community  participation  for  integrated  and  strategic  water 
resources management is critical for sustaining rural livelihoods and safeguarding poor from 
flooding impacts. 
2.  Bangladesh is one of the most disaster-prone countries in the world. The traditional 
disaster management model focusing on disaster relief and recovery has done little to redress 
rising levels of risk. Following the devastating floods in 1988 and the cyclone of 1991, the 
Government adopted a holistic approach, incorporating hazard identification and mitigation, 
community preparedness, and integrated response efforts. The Ministry of Food and Disaster 
Management is the apex institution responsible for coordinating national disaster management 
interventions across all agencies. The National Disaster Management Council, headed by the 
Prime Minister, is the highest forum for the formulation and review of disaster management 
policies. The Inter-Ministerial Disaster Management Coordination Committee is responsible for 
implementing disaster management policies and decisions of National Disaster Management 
Council.  
3.  The  National  Water  Resources  Council  is  the  highest  authority  governing  water 
resources management. The key agencies involved in water resources management are: 
(i)  the Water Resources Planning Organization for policy formulation and macro-
level planning and coordination, 
(ii)  the Bangladesh Water Development Board for water resources management of  
subprojects exceeding 1,000 hectare (ha) and hydrology monitoring, and 
(iii)  the Local Government Engineering Department responsible for projects below 
1,000 ha. 
4.  Sector institutions have been relatively weak in addressing complex water management 
issues. In the past, planning efforts have tended to focus on building infrastructure to protect 
agriculture  and  urban  land  and  often  overlooked  other  aspects.  Key  issues  include  
(i) weaknesses in participatory, integrated, and strategic planning; (ii) agencies that lack the 
capacity to implement water resource interventions while ensuring participatory processes and 
the quality of outputs; (iii) lack of coordination in delivering necessary support services to 
achieve intended economic benefits in agriculture and fisheries; (iv) deficient operation and 
maintenance (O&M) because of lack of beneficiary participation and chronic shortages of funds 
for O&M; and (v) insufficient operational transparency and accountability. 
B.  Supportive Policy and Legislation 
5.  In 1995, the Government launched a major initiative to establish a sound policy, planning, 
institutional, and legal framework for the small-scale water resources sector, following flood 
action plan studies and pilot projects in 1990–1995, which involved coordinated assistance from

16 external funding agencies, including ADB. The National Water Policy (NWP) was prepared 
and approved in 1999. The NWP established sector goals and guidelines to manage critical 
resources effectively, and adopted the principles of integrated water resources management 
with an emphasis on (i) stakeholder participation; (ii) strategic planning; (iii) decentralization;  
(iv)  sound  management  of  social  and  environmental  issues;  (v)  sustainable  O&M  through 
management transfer to water management associations; and (vi) autonomy, transparency, and 
accountability of sector institutions. Guidelines for participatory water management (GPWM),1 
2001 stipulate arrangements for management transfer and local participation in water resources 
schemes. The development of stakeholder-driven water management associations2 is critical to 
the institutional development of community participation in water resources schemes and the 
sustainability of such schemes. 
6.  In 2004, the Government prepared and approved the National Water Management Plan 
(NWMP). This provides a framework for short-, medium-, and long-term strategy and priority 
programs.  Building  on  the  NWP,  the  NWMP  established  programs  covering  (i) institutional 
development,  (ii)  an  enabling  framework,  and  (iii)  agriculture  and  water  management  for 
implementation  to  2030.  In  the  short  term,  the  NWMP  focuses  heavily  on  institutional 
development  and  the  enabling  environment,  along  with  urgent  investment  programs.  The 
NWMP  priorities  include  (i)  promotion  of  rational  management  and  optimal  use  of  water 
resources; and (ii) improvement to the quality of life by ensuring equitable, safe, and reliable 
access to water for production, health and hygiene. The NWMP is currently being updated 
under ADB regional technical assistance3 to identify specific actions for improvement, in the 
areas of river and flood management, riverbank erosion management, drainage improvement, 
and  irrigation  facilities.  A  National  Water  Act  or  Code  will  accommodate  the  vision  and 
provisions of the NWP and facilitate its implementation. 
C.  Donor Harmonization 
7.  One of the alignment indicators of the Paris Declaration4 is to strengthen capacity by 
avoiding parallel implementation structures5 and to encourage shared analysis and/or country 
analytical work, including joint diagnostic reviews. Although harmonization is still in its infancy in 
Bangladesh, there have been efforts in the small-scale water resources management subsector 
to establish a coherent approach by the Government and its development partners. The GPWM 
adopted a common subproject development process and there have been cofinancing projects 
such  as  the  Participatory  Small-Scale  Water  Resources  Sector  Project.  Although  the 
Government  has  yet  to  finalize  its  harmonization  plan,  there  have  been  encouraging 
developments,  such  as  reforms  to  the  procurement  system,  the  enactment  of  the  Public 
Procurement Act, 2006, and efforts to reform the public financial management system.6

1.  Candidate subprojects will follow the basic principles of participatory water resource 
management and specifically:

candidate subproject. The SPFR will follow the requirements and procedures set out in the

updates, and will include:

(v)  implementation arrangements, 
(vi)  initial environmental examination,  
(vii)  resettlement framework, and

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Contribution of the Small-Scale Water Resource Development subsector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh:  
The National Strategy for Accelerated Poverty Reduction (NSAPR) II, 2009–2011 identified the interface between 
water resources management and poverty. It notes the impact of global climate change and identifies water 
resources development and management as a critical sector for achieving pro-poor economic growth and food 
security through agricultural development. The NSAPR II emphasized managing demand and supply during dry 
season, reducing disasters during wet season, carrying out operation and maintenance of infrastructure, building 
additional irrigation facilities, establishing water pricing principles, incorporating environmental considerations, and 
carrying out institutional capacity development for water management. It also stressed the creation of income-
generation opportunities for the poor through water resources management.   
The Project follows two similar projects, the first and second Small-Scale Water Resources Development Sector 
Projects (SSW 1 and SSW 2) and is consistent with NSAPR II. Effect monitoring and evaluation of those projects 
revealed significant incremental agriculture production, which is critical to the livelihoods of the poor and to mitigate 
the current food crisis. Surveys and field visits at sample subproject sites indicated that the Project is expected to 
generate substantial temporary employment in construction and long-term employment associated with the increase 
in agricultural and fisheries production. The Project will attempt to address the poverty of beneficiaries living and 
farming in subproject areas by small-scale water resource development that will provide (i) drainage, (ii) flood 
management, (iii) water conservation, (iv) command area development, and (v) institutional development. The main 
employment window for the rural poor will be in seasonal construction and as sharecroppers.  
ADB’s Country Strategy and Program (CSP) for Bangladesh, 2006–2010, identified expansion of access to irrigation 
and associated flood protection through command area and small-scale water resource management as a key 
strategy. The CSP also emphasized building country capacity and ensuring community participation (especially by 
the disadvantaged and women) in designing and implementing projects. The Project is consistent with the CSP. 
Water management cooperative associations (WMCA) will be formed in each subproject area by the beneficiaries 
and about one-third of the members of WMCAs will be women. The WMCAs will eventually be responsible for 
operation and maintenance of the infrastructure to ensure that project benefits are sustainable. The WMCAs will bring 
all types of beneficiaries under a single umbrella, ensure participation of various groups, and ensure benefits accrue 
to these groups, especially the poor and vulnerable. The WMCA will also be oriented and trained on operation and 
maintenance of the infrastructure.

management, water conservation, drainage, command area development, jobs, access to capital and productive 
skills for livelihood support. The WMCAs will provide a platform to increase the participation of the poor and 
vulnerable in community development decisions.

SUMMARY FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Approach and Methodology 
1.  The basic assumptions used for economic analysis include the following: (i) the world 
price numeraire was used; (ii) base costs and benefits are in June 2008 terms with conversion 
factors to adopt domestic prices to international prices; (iii) Bangladesh taka (Tk) was the unit of 
account (the exchange rate used is for 2008, when Tk68 = $1); (iv) a standard conversion factor 
of 0.91 and a shadow wage rate of 0.9 for unskilled labor were used; (v) economic values of 
major tradable commodities were based on border parity pricing and standard methods of 
deriving farmgate output and input prices were applied; and (vi) transfer payments such as 
taxes and subsidies were excluded in the calculation of economic values. 
2.  For  each  of  the  three  sample  subprojects,1 estimates  of  cropping  patterns  and 
technologies in the with-Project and without-Project scenarios were based on expected changes 
in land use due to flood protection and/or increased availability of water for crops. Per hectare 
costs of production and returns for relevant crops were calculated and translated into economic 
values.  For  the  subprojects’  net  benefited  area,  the  incremental  value  of  production  was 
calculated. Some subprojects (for example Goshinga) may be expected to have an effect upon 
capture  fisheries.  Operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  were  estimated  at  6%  of 
construction costs for earthworks and 0.5% of the cost of structures.2 Benefits and costs are 
expressed as cash flow streams over an expected 20 years of subproject life from which 
economic and financial internal rates of return (EIRR and FIRR) are calculated. Sensitivity 
analyses were performed by assuming various scenarios relating to particular risk factors such 
as shortened project life due to poor O&M, delays in project benefits, increased construction 
costs,  decreased  benefits,  and  rice  price  fluctuation.  Agricultural  production  benefits  are 
generally assumed to accrue to landowners and operators. Household income is expected to 
increase  from  incremental  labor  utilization  with  the  subprojects.  Improved  water  resource 
regimes allow farmers to more fully adopt technology for high-yield varieties and labor inputs 
can be expected to rise to some extent. In local financial terms this increase in labor income can 
add substantially to household income, particularly that of the poor.

4.  Economic  benefits  were  calculated  from  the  incremental  value  of  crop  production 
generated  by  the  subproject,  net  of  production  cost  at  economic  input  and  output  prices. 
Livestock benefits were included by valuing fodder and crop residues. Fishery benefits were 
modeled directly for canal, flood, and fish pond activities but were small compared with crop 
benefits (about 10% of total benefits). Project benefits excluded from the analysis included 
improved  navigation  in  drainage  canals,  environmental  and  health  benefits  from  improved 
nutrition, and better water management and drainage. The area of cereal crops grown will 
remain more or less constant at around 143,000 ha but cropping intensity will increase because 
of land use changes and flood management, leading to an anticipated overall increase of 34% 
in paddy rice production. Current overall cropping intensity is 161% and this is expected to 
increase to 173% with the boro area increasing from 69% to 76% of total cropped area.  
5.  Paddy rice production dominates agricultural production and rice is a major food product. 
Bangladesh  imports  rice  when  export  item  harvests  are  poor  due to  climatic events.  This 
situation is expected to continue in the medium term. No problem is envisaged in marketing the 
increased rice production. Incremental project rice production has been valued on the basis of 
its farm gate equivalent price. The estimated export parity farm gate price for paddy was Tk18 
per kilogram (kg) in January 2009 (using a world price of $580 per ton), and the import parity 
price was Tk23 per kg. This compares with a support price of Tk17.5 per kg. Domestic paddy 
rice prices usually lie somewhere between export and import parity levels as most rice is used 
domestically and only a small proportion is traded. Mean rice prices in 2008 were $650 per ton, 
compared with $286 in 2005, and $580 in January 2009.3 World Bank price projections show 
the real price of rice falling back to $404 per ton from 2010, but this will still be higher than 2007 
levels. This gives rice a conversion factor ranging from 0.8 to 1.5, depending on the world price 
adopted. Using 2010 price,s the conversion factor is 1.0, and this was used in the economic 
analysis.  
6.  Other grains were a minor part of the market. Bangladesh is currently a net importer of 
wheat. Long-term wheat prices are expected to fall below 2007 values, but wheat prices have 
been relatively stable, even in 2008. Calculated wheat prices were based on world prices for 
wheat in 2010 at import parity. The farm gate price was Tk23.3 per kg, compared with the 
support price of Tk29.1 per kg, giving a conversion factor of 0.8. 
7.  Prices of inputs, especially fertilizer, rose dramatically in the first 6 months of 2008. 
Fertilizer prices are being driven by rising demand associated with biofuel production, and by 
the rising price of oil. In Bangladesh, the cost of production of urea is reported to be Tk50,000 
per ton ($735), while the Government has set the farm gate price (June 2008), at Tk12,000 per

the World Bank commodity price series were used. Future prices were based on the most 
recent available price forecast (November 2008). The domestic financial price of urea is very 
low. Even at 2007 prices, a conversion factor of 2.5 is required, and a conversion factor of 3.5 is 
required if mean 2008 world prices are used. The detailed economic and financial analysis in 
Supplementary Appendix K shows that forecast urea world prices are expected to fall below 
2007 prices in real terms, while it is likely that large domestic subsidies will be maintained. A 
long-term conversion factor based on forecast 2010 prices, of 2.2, looks most realistic, and was

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK AND SHORT RESETTLEMENT PLANS 
 
A.  Introduction  
1.  This  appendix  summarizes  the  project  resettlement  framework  and  three  sample 
subproject short resettlement plans. The original resettlement framework and resettlement plans 
are in Supplementary Appendix N.  
2.  The resettlement framework guides the formulation of subproject resettlement plans. 
Considering the high level of beneficiary participation in the Project and the relatively minor land 
acquisition per subproject, a negotiated settlement for land acquisition is preferred to a formal 
land acquisition process. Compensation will be paid for all land acquired for the Project based 
on its replacement cost. The Government and the Local Government Engineering Department 
(LGED) as the Executing Agency will ensure open negotiations with affected peoples and will 
engage an independent external party to document, validate, and record the process. The 
documentation will be shared with ADB. 
3.  The basis principle enshrined in the resettlement framework is that everyone affected by 
the Project—titled and non-titled—is eligible for an appropriate compensation package. The key 
compensation principles are (i) land acquisition and resettlement (LAR) will be avoided or at 
least minimized; (ii) compensation paid on the basis of replacement cost will guarantee at least 
the  maintenance  of  the  affected  family’s  living  standards  before  the  Project;  (iii)  affected 
households  will  be  fully  informed  and  consulted  on  the  Project,  land  acquisition  and 
compensation packages and options; (iv) LAR provisions will apply equally to women and men; 
(v) particular attention will be paid to vulnerable groups and households headed by women in 
providing compensation and resettlement assistance and efforts will be made to improve their 
household income; (vi) LAR will be conceived and executed as an integral part of the project 
and LAR budgets will be included in project costs; and (vii) no work contract will be awarded 
under  any  subproject  until  compensation  packages  are  provided  to  affected  people.  The 
entitlements of various categories of affected people are listed in the entitlement matrix in 
Supplementary Appendix N.
